title: Unlock performance issue

labels.name: performance
labels.description: Improve performance of an existing feature

body:
Situation: ~22k small files about 24KB each.

```
action summary:
  unlock (ok: 21840)
datalad unlock functional  252.34s user 17.42s system 97% cpu 4:36.33 total
```

for context on the general performance of the FS: when I actually load all these files, modify them with a command and store copies into another folder it takes a total of ~12s.

Using the annex cmdline is actually slower than using datalad (which generates the same number of lines on stdout) -- no sure how we managed to achieve that.

```
git annex unlock functional  296.57s user 49.33s system 101% cpu 5:40.28 total
```

for comparison an fsck run (actually iterating over even more files, hence more output on stdout):

```
git annex fsck  75.89s user 10.30s system 101% cpu 1:24.95 total
```

When I bypass unlock with a bash for-loop (likely not the fastest approach), I am 4-5x faster -- and seemingly achieve the same result:

```
% time bash -c 'for i in $(find functional/dicoms -type l); do cp --remove-destination $(readlink -f $i) $i; done'
bash -c   39.21s user 13.70s system 103% cpu 51.339 total
```

@joeyh is unlock doing something in addition to replacing the symlink with a copy of the annexed file?

Moreover: Putting the modified files back into annex is also slow. While that actually requires some more work, it should not be *much* more than what fsck does, and probably not more than fsck and unlock combined, but that is the case here:

```
% git add .
git add .  10.31s user 1.57s system 99% cpu 11.929 total
...
git commit --amend  588.24s user 46.04s system 100% cpu 10:28.18 total
```
